com.google.mu.util

Class Substring

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.google.mu.util.Substring

  • public final class Substring
extends Object
    A substring inside a string, providing easy access to substrings around it (before, after or with the substring itself removed, replaced etc.).

    For example, to strip off the "http://" prefix from a uri string if existent: 

       static String stripHttp(String uri) {
     return Substring.prefix("http://").removeFrom(uri);
   }
    To strip off either "http://" or "https://" prefix: 
       static import com.google.mu.util.Substring.prefix;
 
   static String stripHttpOrHttps(String uri) {
     return prefix("http://").or(prefix("https://")).removeFrom(uri);
   }
    To strip off the suffix starting with a dash (-) character: 
       static String stripDashSuffix(String str) {
     return Substring.from(last('-')).removeFrom(str);
   }
    To replace trailing "//" with "/": 
       static String fixTrailingSlash(String str) {
     return Substring.suffix("//").replaceFrom(str, '/');
   }
    To extract the 'name' and 'value' from texts in the format of "name:value": 
       String str = ...;
   Substring colon = Substring.first(':').in(str).orElseThrow(BadFormatException::new);
   String name = colon.getBefore();
   String value = colon.getAfter();
    Since:
    2.0

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      static class  Substring.Pattern
      A substring pattern that can be matched against a string to find substrings.

      Pattern that matches all strings entirely.

      Pattern that never matches any substring.

      • regex

        public static Substring.Pattern regex(Pattern regexPattern)
        Returns a Pattern that matches the first occurrence of regexPattern.

        Unlike str.replaceFirst(regexPattern, replacement), 

        regex(regexPattern).replaceFrom(str, replacement)
        treats the replacement as a literal string with no special handling of backslash (\) and dollar sign ($) characters.

      • regex

        public static Substring.Pattern regex(String regexPattern)
        Returns a Pattern that matches the first occurrence of regexPattern.

        Unlike str.replaceFirst(regexPattern, replacement), 

        regex(regexPattern).replaceFrom(str, replacement)
        treats the replacement as a literal string with no special handling of backslash (\) and dollar sign ($) characters.

        Because this method internally compiles regexPattern, it's more efficient to reuse the returned Substring.Pattern object than calling regex(regexPattern) repetitively.

      • regexGroup

        public static Substring.Pattern regexGroup(Pattern regexPattern,
                                           int group)
        Returns a Pattern that matches capturing group of regexPattern.

        The returned Pattern will throw IndexOutOfBoundsException when matched against strings without the target group.

      • regexGroup

        public static Substring.Pattern regexGroup(String regexPattern,
                                           int group)
        Returns a Pattern that matches capturing group of regexPattern.

        Unlike str.replaceFirst(regexPattern, replacement), 

        regexGroup(regexPattern, group).replaceFrom(str, replacement)
        treats the replacement as a literal string with no special handling of backslash (\) and dollar sign ($) characters.

        Because this method internally compiles regexPattern, it's more efficient to reuse the returned Substring.Pattern object than calling regexGroup(regexPattern, group) repetitively.

        The returned Pattern will throw IndexOutOfBoundsException when matched against strings without the target group.

      • last

        public static Substring.Pattern last(char c)
        Returns a Pattern that matches the last occurrence of c.

      • last

        public static Substring.Pattern last(String snippet)
        Returns a Pattern that matches the last occurrence of snippet.

      • before

        public static Substring.Pattern before(Substring.Pattern delimiter)
        Returns a Pattern that covers the substring before delimiter. For example: 
           String startFromDoubleSlash = Substring.before(first("//")).removeFrom(uri);
        Since:
        2.1

      • after

        public static Substring.Pattern after(Substring.Pattern delimiter)
        Returns a Pattern that covers the substring after delimiter. For example: 
           String endWithPeriod = Substring.after(last(".")).removeFrom(line);
        Since:
        2.1

      • from

        public static Substring.Pattern from(Substring.Pattern startingPoint)
        Returns a Pattern that will match from staringPoint to the end of the input string. For example: 
           String commentRemoved = Substring.from(first("//")).removeFrom(line);
        Since:
        2.1

      • upTo

        public static Substring.Pattern upTo(Substring.Pattern endingPoint)
        Returns a Pattern that will match from the beginning of the input string up to endingPoint inclusively. For example: 
           String schemeStripped = Substring.upTo(first("://")).removeFrom(uri);
        Since:
        2.1

      • between

        public static Substring.Pattern between(Substring.Pattern open,
                                        Substring.Pattern close)
        Returns a Pattern that will match the substring between open and close. For example: 
           String quoted = Substring.between(first('('), first(')'))
       .from(input)
       .orElseThrow(...);
        Since:
        2.1

      • getBefore

        public String getBefore()
        Returns part before this substring.

        getBefore() and getAfter() are almost always used together to split a string into two parts. Prefer using upTo(com.google.mu.util.Substring.Pattern) if you are trying to find a prefix ending with a pattern, like: 

           String schemeStripped = Substring.upTo(first("://")).removeFrom(uri);
        or using from(com.google.mu.util.Substring.Pattern) to find a suffix starting with a pattern: 
           String commentRemoved = Substring.from(first("//")).removeFrom(line);

      • getAfter

        public String getAfter()
        Returns part after this substring.

        getBefore() and getAfter() are almost always used together to split a string into two parts. Prefer using upTo(com.google.mu.util.Substring.Pattern) if you are trying to find a prefix ending with a pattern, like: 

           String schemeStripped = Substring.upTo(first("://")).removeFrom(uri);
        or using Substring.Pattern.from(java.lang.String) to find a suffix starting with a pattern: 
           String commentRemoved = Substring.from(first("//")).removeFrom(line);
